PT0M43S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings 10 things 'Back to the Future Part II' predicted we'd have by now How well do you know Back to the Future? Twenty-six years ago this week, the film Back to the Future Part II depicted October 21, 2015 – today – as a day when people would travel in flying cars powered by compact fusion reactors, kids would scoot by on hover boards and families would watch holographic movies.
In the past week, there has already been plenty of commentary about which inventions dreamt up by the film's director, Robert Zemeckis, and writer Bob Gale, have come true (Large flat-screen TVs, yes, flux capacitors, no).
We have acheived this in 2015: Video calling in the 1989 film Back to the Future II Photo: Supplied
Perhaps the bigger question is: if Back to the Future Part II set up a technological measuring stick in 1989 for what things could or should look like today, how is the future looking from here?
Advertisement Since Michael J. Fox starred as Marty McFly in the second instalment of the trilogy, cheap, ubiquitous computing has reshaped the world. The internet has transformed societies, helping depose leaders, and redirect national conversations. Advances in medical science have continued apace. GPS has become a given and even satellite launches, once a matter of wonder, are routine.
"Some technologies of the past 30 years have far exceeded all expectations," Denny Oetomo, a robotics professor from the University of Melbourne, says.
Electronic glasses in Back to the Future II, but the double ties never caught on. Photo: Supplied
But Oetomo notes that in other areas, technological innovation has disappointed.
Mass market innovations in batteries remain scarce. Without rapid advances in fuel cells, other inventions are impossible. There has been no major innovation in transportation. Cars run on the same petrol they did in 1989.
"We haven't quite taken care of our environment," Oetomo said. "We're still burning fossil fuels. We're still on coal."
The future wasn't all bad as depicted in 1989. Michael J Fox in Back to the Future Part II. Photo: Supplied
If Back to the Future Part II forms a measure to judge ourselves by, viewing the film today begs the question whether in 2015 – the real 2015 – we're on track to develop the needed technology to face the challenges in the new century.
That's a question Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has been wrestling with. In announcing his new cabinet last month, he warned that if Australia wants to "remain a prosperous, First World economy " it must be more competitive and more productive. "Above all we must be more innovative."
Swinburne University of Technology innovation lecturer Bert Verhoeven​ says technological advancement hasn't run out of steam.
Back to the Future – the trilogy played with time and depicted a positive 2015. Photo: Supplied
"I am an optimist and believe that the idea machine has not broken down yet."
Yet the debate about the pace of innovation rests on how much impact future advancements will have compared with those of the past.
"Do, for example, future innovations like virtual reality, self-driving cars, genetics or personal robots have more or less influence on how we live than innovations from the past like electricity, the combustion engine or the telephone?"
Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) and his hover board. Photo: Nicky Phillips
The first Back to the Future instalment let viewers look back with nostalgia at the technological progress from 1955 to 1985, Melbourne University screen studies professor Angela Ndalianis says.
" Back to the Future Part II is the one that's most about what our future is going to be," she said, and it did "incite the imagination of the public, including scientists".
Gale said he and Zemeckis wanted to avoid the dystopian bent of Blade Runner . "We wanted people to look forward to the future because, when we were kids, we always looked forward to the future."
Curiously, since the film's premiere, the sci-fi film genre has continued down a more dystopian path with such works as the Minority Report , Prometheus , AI .
Asked why, Ndalianis says the dystopian focus in films nearly always relates to a fear of science and technology in the hands of military and government.
"These films are very much this moral story of what can happen to humanity if we don't control how we're using science." In the time of the Edward Snowden revelations, Islamic State terror on social media, or the recognition that governments use drones to target their own citizens in extrajudicial killings, such fears can hardly be a surprise.
But the fear so prevalent in sci-fi films in recent years has some wondering if it's actually holding back the collective imagination and sense of possibility the public needs to seek and achieve positive technological change.
PayPal co-founder Peter Thiel​ laments the hostility to technology in many blockbuster films, saying, in effect, it turns the public off from the possibilities of science and technology.
Ndalianis doesn't see an end to the string of dystopian films because of worries about the future of technology.
"I think at the moment, we're in such incredible times of transition," she said, with "reality and illusion" blurring into each other. These more dystopian films "ask us to be hesitant and philosophical in shaping that future that lies ahead".
Some technology thinkers, noting the trend toward the dystopian, have begun a more conscious embrace of positive science fiction. It's not just "where is my flying car?" But where is the hope and expectation of a flying car? Or a colony on Mars? Or transportation that is clean, efficient and doesn't damage the environment? In other words: the big, risky projects that challenge humanity and come with big rewards.
No less a figure than Elon Musk, the man behind SpaceX and Tesla, has been reading "semi-utopian" sci-fi. In honour of late author Iain M. Banks, who conjured highly evolved, post-scarcity worlds, Musk had the names of sentient spacecraft from his books painted on SpaceX's drone ships. Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg has also put Banks' work on his reading list.
But the trend in sci-fi films is still overwhelmingly negative. In this climate, Back to the Future Part II 's real value today, may not be the many inventions it nearly got right, but the fact that the film envisioned the world to come as a positive place.
The optimism may be a relic of the 1980s but something the public may need today to confront the challenges of the future.
University of Melbourne Professor Angela Ndalianis and Dr Denny Oetomo will present Back to the Future II at a special screening at Hoyt's Melbourne Central on Wednesday.
